events.originalText: Bus drivers in Greater Manchester began an eleven-week strike, one of the longest in British transportation history.
events.subtitle: Greater Manchester
events.headline: Bus drivers in Greater Manchester on eleven-week strike

events.originalText: Benedict XVI became the first pope in nearly 600 years to resign from the papacy.
events.subtitle: Pope Benedict XVI
events.headline: Benedict XVI resigns from papacy

events.originalText: During a period of religious violence in Gujarat, India, mobs of Hindus attacked Muslims in Naroda Patiya and in Chamanpura, resulting in 166 deaths.
events.subtitle: 2002 Gujarat riots
events.headline: Religious violence in Gujarat results in 166 deaths

events.originalText: A high-speed train crash occurred near Selby in North Yorkshire, England, killing 10 and injuring 82.
events.subtitle: Selby rail crash
events.headline: High-speed train crash near Selby kills 10

events.originalText: GRB 970228, a highly luminous 80-second flash of gamma rays, was detected on Earth, providing early evidence that gamma-ray bursts occur well beyond the Milky Way.
events.subtitle: GRB 970228
events.headline: Gamma-ray burst detected on Earth

events.originalText: Two heavily armed bank robbers exchanged gunfire with officers of the Los Angeles Police Department in North Hollywood, in one of the most intense gun battles in American police history.
events.subtitle: North Hollywood shootout
events.headline: Intense gun battle in North Hollywood

events.originalText: The Troubles: The Provisional Irish Republican Army launched a mortar attack on a Royal Ulster Constabulary station in Newry, Northern Ireland, killing nine people.
events.subtitle: The Troubles
events.headline: IRA mortar attack in Newry kills nine

events.originalText: A London Underground train failed to stop at the terminal Moorgate station, crashing and causing the deaths of 43 people.
events.subtitle: London Underground
events.headline: London Underground crash kills 43

events.originalText: The British election ended in a hung parliament after the Jeremy Thorpe-led Liberal Party achieved their biggest vote.
events.subtitle: February 1974 United Kingdom general election
events.headline: British election ends in hung parliament

events.originalText: Japanese police stormed a mountain lodge near Karuizawa, Nagano Prefecture, to end a ten-day siege by members of the paramilitary group United Red Army.
events.subtitle: Law enforcement in Japan
events.headline: Japanese police end mountain lodge siege

events.originalText: Chicago alderman Benjamin F. Lewis was murdered in his office by unknown assailants two days after having been reelected.
events.subtitle: Benjamin F. Lewis
events.headline: Chicago alderman Benjamin F. Lewis murdered

events.originalText: Nationalist soldiers fired on protesters in Taipei (crowd pictured), triggering widespread uprisings and the violent suppression in the Taiwanese White Terror.
events.subtitle: Nationalist government
events.headline: Nationalist soldiers fire on protesters in Taipei

events.originalText: In one of the most famous errors in lexicography, the erroneous word "dord" was discovered in Webster's New International Dictionary by an editor.
events.subtitle: Lexicography
events.headline: Erroneous word 'dord' found in dictionary

events.originalText: Indian physicist C. V. Raman and his colleagues discovered what is now known as Raman scattering, for which he later became the first Asian to win the Nobel Prize in Physics.
events.subtitle: C. V. Raman
events.headline: C. V. Raman wins Nobel Prize in Physics

events.originalText: In the aftermath of the Balkan Wars, Greeks living in southern Albania proclaimed the short-lived Autonomous Republic of Northern Epirus.
events.subtitle: Balkan Wars
events.headline: Autonomous Republic of Northern Epirus proclaimed

events.originalText: The most successful football club in Portugal, S.L. Benfica, was founded in Lisbon as Sport Lisboa.
events.subtitle: Association football
events.headline: S.L. Benfica founded in Lisbon

events.originalText: Ranavalona III, the last sovereign ruler of the Kingdom of Madagascar, was deposed by French military forces.
events.subtitle: Ranavalona III
events.headline: Ranavalona III deposed by French forces

events.originalText: USS Indiana, the lead ship of her class and the first battleship in the United States Navy comparable to foreign battleships of the time, was launched.
events.subtitle: USS Indiana (BB-1)
events.headline: USS Indiana launched

events.originalText: In one of the longest cases ever heard in an English court, the claimant in the Tichborne case was convicted of perjury for attempting to assume the identity of the missing heir to the Tichborne baronetcy.
events.subtitle: Tichborne case
events.headline: Tichborne case claimant convicted of perjury

events.originalText: A gun on USS Princeton exploded while the warship cruised on the Potomac River, killing six people and injuring twenty others.
events.subtitle: USS Princeton (1843)
events.headline: Explosion on USS Princeton kills six

events.originalText: The National Covenant was formally adopted in opposition to proposed reforms to the Church of Scotland by King Charles I.
events.subtitle: National Covenant
events.headline: National Covenant adopted in opposition to reforms

events.originalText: Rebel leader Liu Bang declared himself Emperor Gaozu of Han after overthrowing the Qin dynasty, the first imperial dynasty of China.
events.subtitle: Emperor Gaozu of Han
events.headline: Liu Bang declares himself Emperor Gaozu of Han
